basics.name: Dana (Dhahyun) Kang
basics.label: Mechanical Engineer
basics.summary: I'm a 2nd year master's student at the University of Maryland, College Park, majoring in Mechanical Engineering and a certified Engineer-in-Training working towards a Professional Engineer license. I am passionate about sustainability and dedicated to reducing fossil fuel use through strategic electrification and the implementation of energy efficient technologies.

work.name: Center for Environmental Energy Engineering, University of Maryland
work.summary: My current research is focused on developing a building energy model for a high-efficiency cold climate heat pump system.

work.name: Optimized Energy Conversion Systems Lab, Korea University

volunteer.organization: ASHRAE University of Maryland Student Branch
volunteer.summary: Lead organizer for the New York City branch of the People's Climate March, the largest climate march in history.
highlights: Awarded 'Climate Hero' award by Greenpeace for my efforts organizing the march.
Men of the year 2014 by Time magazine

awards.title: ASHRAE Graduate Grant-in-Aid
awards.awarder: American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers

certificates.name: Engineer-in-Training
certificates.issuer: Texas Board of Professional Engineers and Land Surveyors

publications.name: Multi-Stage Heat Pump with Two-Phase Injection for Cold Climate Applications Implementing Natural Refrigerants
Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
